comments.commentBody: You've outdone yourself this evening, John! I agree with you completely! Had Romney been president when the Tea Party won all those seats in 2010, would he have flip-flopped or tried to squash them?
How much do I like those tweaks -- Obama up, Romney down -- from this latest polling? Much. Let this be the first step of a long trend.

There is a fundamental flaw in this analysis. The 'valuation' of apartments is only unfair if smaller units and houses are 'valued' differently. In fact, valuing owner-occupied apartments at rental value means that owners pay higher taxes than owners of one and two family houses throughout the city.

Since homeownerets of all varieties of housing in the City pay based on significant 'undervaluing' there is little disparity, and little unfairness.

And, there is A strong quid pro quo for the 421-a abatement, the builder must create 20% affordable units.

The NYT's "Residential Sales Around the Region" shows this absurdity week after week. Single family properties in Queens and elsewhere are massively over-assessed compared to those in the most affluent sections of Brooklyn. And the situation with co-ops and condos is almost as bad, and made worse by the senseless policy of giving tax abatements to luxury developments, even in the middle of an unprecedented RE boom. It's a slap in the face to people who buy in "affordable" neighborhoods. But the city government seems to prefer elaborate subsidy plans to common sense. After all, tax abatements help developers. It's time RE taxes, for all types of residential properties, were tied to market value, pure and simple.

No, if you got rid of rent control and public housing, prices would skyrocket, and there'd be a few hundred thousand more homeless people.

Rent control was created and continues to exist because New York has had a chronic housing shortage for more than 60 years, and if the market were allowed to set rents, they would be far beyond what the vast majority of New Yorkers could afford--as has happened since they were weakened in 1997.

Also, public infrastructure--subways, electricity, water, etc.--contributes to the value of property in New York. So those who benefit from that should give something back to the community instead of hogging it and insulting the people who have less.
More theft by the 1%.
NYC is 'liberal' in the European sense of the word....

So you want to discourage short term trading AND stop encouraging long term investing?

Short term traders are already penalized by paying higher capital gains taxes than long term investors. Raising long term capital gains rates will only encourage investors to become more active traders which by the way only benefits Wall St.

And neither bankers nor high frequency traders benefit from low long term capital gains or dividend taxes, your average long term investor (ie person with any savings in stocks or mutual funds) does.

Carried interest is income and should rightly be taxed that way but is irrelevant to the stock market. The only related take away from this article is that access to market data costs $25k a month now that exchanges are for profit operations and transaction costs (an actual harm to long term investor returns) may head higher with less competing market makers.

Romney in the primary tmade clear that he would fight for conservative principles, many he appears to have abandoned, although the clarity he insists he will bring to foreign policy is severely absent in the details of his domestic policies. What details he cites, like coverage for pre-existing conditions, as Paul Krugman pointed out, is often misrepresented, deliberately. He knowingly and willfully repeats lies. He breaches the trust of voters. And he never mentions Congress, promising what purports to be backroom deals on health care, budgets, and safety nets.

Under Romney, earmarks would be implemented in reverse. Find the regulation or standard or authority that protects health or the environment, and target it to be cut by placing it unnoticed in a giant deficit reduction bill, or as an amendment to legislation. Defunding will be a trend as rules and functions will be micro-targeted for extinction. Regulations on coal? Gone! The requirement that 80% of health premiums be used for actual care, gone. The give away of leases for mining and drilling on federal lands and waters, increased. On arcane issues with FCC or EPA oversight, the advantage will be handed to businesses without the public knowing.

Most of these acts wil be hidden in legislation written by lobbyists who we never see, as Romney's campaign is funded by money we don't know about and based on details he refuses to reveal.

Remember, this is the same party that called the BP escrow account a slush fund.

Mr. Romney is no leader. He would have capitulated to whatever crazy demands would have been made of him by the extreme right, in his belief that in order to lead, he has to swing their way. I guess we'll find out very soon whether his choice was the right one.

"Third, it does require the ability to count. The governing craftsman has to be able to know how many votes each side possesses. He has to avoid the narcissistic question: What do I want? He has to ask instead: Given this correlation of forces, what is the landscape offering me?"

Were he capable, he would never have run the kind of campaign he's running now. If he wins and the Tea Party Republicans continue to have the influence they have now, they'll eat him alive.

The problem with this analysis is that Republican operatives control the voting process and apparatus in several key states, including Ohio and Florida. If you're counting on a fair election process in these states, think again. Particularly in Ohio, which in large part has moved away from manual ballots in favor of non-transparent electronic voting machines, the process is fraught with risk for Democrats. This reduces the natural favorability of the  electoral map for Obama/Biden.

Three weeks to go and if Obama just breaks even tomorrow he ought to win. While Nate's point regarding the national and state polls eventually connecting ay prove true, the edge Obama has in the electoral college should hold up. Though he has lost most of his big leads in contested states, he still holds a definite edge in all of Kerry's 2004 states plus New Mexico plus Ohio. That's 269 electoral votes that Romney will have to gain still more traction to win. If he doesn't get it in the debates, it's hard to see where it will come from. And one more state puts Obama over the top.

The SR-71 had a top speed of Mach 3.2+ (c. 2200 mph) and required a titanium airframe because of the 500 degree F heat generated at that speed. The shuttle at reentry had a speed of about 17,500 mph, or nearly Mach 25. Hence the tiles on it and other space capsules.

With temperature as low as -50 C in the stratosphere I would guess that even at Mach 1 the cold was a more significant problem than heat generation.

While all the focus has rightly been on the man's achievement, I am curious about the speed the capsule reached after being released from the balloon. Was Newton right? Well, sure, but it would be nice to know the top speed.

Oh, but wait. Evangelicals are rarely found in public schools today because they left, en masse, to hide within the four walls of their Christian/church schools.

Perhaps my greatest grievance is the manner in which the NYCM has been lottery-ized by exploiting running enthusiasts to create a mammoth revenue machine that supports the NYRR president's high salary and global travel, as well as six-figure appearance money for marquee runners favored by her who perennially underperform.
Every other marathon has a cut-off point at which registration ends. However, the NYCM allows for unlimited registration and charges (the last time I registered) $12 per registrant. Some 150,000 runners register for the lottery, and about 60,000 are selected for the marathon.
That is $1.8 million total, and $1.1 million from runners who essentially register for naught.
Surely it does not cost $12 to input a race registration in an Excel file, and why charge the 90,000 enthusiasts who are not selected (there is/was a NYRR policy that if you are not selected in the lottery three consecutive years, you automatically qualify the fourth)?
And at least one year - NYRR officials will confirm - thousands of registrations where simply ignored and not included in a lottery process.
I also have a problem with Wittenberg seeking ownership of running in NYC, successfully fighting attempts by other organizations to stage a spring marathon which could accommodate runners' demand that cannot be met alone by the NYCM. Instead of sharing NYC, Wittenberg opts for the stultifying wave starts, or the capricious idea of making the marathon a twin event over two days.

I just submitted a comment that is under review. I need to clarify that the $12 registration fee mentioned applies only to the marathon lottery. In other words there is a $12 lottery-registration fee in order to have the opportunity to actually register for the marathon at a cost of some $200.
